cards.title: Plants & How They Grow
cards.summary: Plants use light, water, and air to grow and make their own food — and you can grow them too.

cards.title: Crafts & Gentle STEM
cards.summary: Simple, fun activities you can do at home with everyday stuff — and learn real science while you create.

cards.title: Cats of the World
cards.summary: From house cats to lions, tigers, and lynx — one family of hunters, the Felidae, with dozens of species and a shared way of life.

cards.title: Dogs & Their Relatives
cards.summary: Dogs, wolves, foxes, and their cousins — the Canidae family. From our best friends to wild hunters and survivors.

cards.title: Sloths
cards.summary: Life in slow motion: sloths are rainforest mammals that move slowly, hang upside down, and host a whole world in their fur.

cards.title: Raccoons
cards.summary: The masked neighbor: raccoons are adaptable, smart mammals that live beside us in woods, suburbs, and cities — and thrive by using their hands.

cards.title: Opossums & Relatives
cards.summary: North America's only marsupial: the Virginia opossum and its cousins. They play possum, eat pests, and carry their babies in a pouch.

cards.title: Giant Pandas & Red Pandas
cards.summary: Two very different pandas: the giant panda is a bamboo-eating bear from China; the red panda is a small, tree-dwelling cousin of raccoons — both need forests and our care.

cards.title: Goats, Sheep & Cows
cards.summary: Familiar livestock that live beside us: how they were domesticated, how they live, and why they matter for food, fiber, and farms.

cards.title: Birds
cards.summary: Feathers, flight, and migration: birds are the most visible migrators on Earth, with thousands of species from backyard songbirds to raptors and ocean wanderers.

cards.title: Whales
cards.summary: The largest animals on Earth: whales are marine mammals that sing, migrate, and filter krill or hunt squid — and they need healthy oceans to survive.

cards.title: Sharks
cards.summary: More than 500 species, from hand-sized to bus-length: sharks are ancient predators that keep ocean ecosystems in balance — and they need our protection, not our fear.

cards.title: Crabs, Octopus & Squid
cards.summary: Smart arms and hard shells: crabs, octopuses, and squids are ocean invertebrates that solve problems, change color, and fill the sea with wonder.

cards.title: Snakes, Lizards & Turtles
cards.summary: Scaly and ancient: reptiles include snakes, lizards, and turtles — they lay eggs on land, breathe with lungs, and live on every continent except Antarctica.

cards.title: Frogs, Toads & Salamanders
cards.summary: The slimy and the moist: amphibians live double lives in water and on land — and they are among the most threatened animals on Earth.

cards.title: Spiders & Their Relatives
cards.summary: Eight legs, silk, and venom: spiders, scorpions, and their arachnid relatives are predators and builders — and most are harmless to people.

cards.title: Beetles, Flies, Mosquitoes & Insect Relatives
cards.summary: Six legs and endless variety: insects include beetles, flies, mosquitoes, bees, and butterflies — pollinators, decomposers, and some pests we learn to live with.

cards.title: Platypus, Capybara & Other Unique Creatures
cards.summary: Egg-laying mammals and the world's largest rodent: the platypus and capybara are just two of the planet's most surprising and beloved animals.

cards.title: Marsupials: Kangaroos, Koalas & More
cards.summary: Pouches and joeys: kangaroos, koalas, wallabies, and wombats are marsupials — mammals that raise their tiny young in a pouch until they are ready for the world.
